children.text: Investors looked to the European Central Bank to judge policymakers' response to the situation in Ukraine, while equity-index futures and European equities
slid amid concerns that U.S. inflation rose for the sixth month in a row.

After U.S. stocks soared to their highest level since June 2020 on Wednesday, contracts expiring this month on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 indexes each fell at least 0.6 percent. Before the ECB's policy choices this afternoon, Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell for the fifth time in six days, and the euro fell. Treasuries and the dollar were up, while oil was down.

Russia's cutoff from global economic ties has wreaked havoc on commodity markets, raising concerns about a further slowdown in global growth and a spike in inflation already fuelled by Covid-related supply disruptions. Investors are discussing whether the ECB and the Federal Reserve, which meet next week, will place a higher priority on limiting consumer prices or supporting economic recovery.

Stocks in the United States rose on Wednesday after a top foreign policy advisor to Ukraine's president indicated the country was willing to consider Russia's demand for neutrality if security assurances were provided. The United Arab Emirates announced hours later that it will urge the OPEC+ partnership to expand oil output more quickly, though the energy minister later appeared to moderate that message.

Oil prices climbed on Thursday, with WTI contracts trading above $114 per barrel. Investors are unable to assess the full impact of the war on supply-demand dynamics, which is causing more dramatic fluctuations in commodity prices than usual.

Amazon.com Inc. soared 7% in premarket trade in New York after announcing a share split and a $10 billion buyback plan. Baidu Inc. and JD.com Inc., both Chinese online-commerce companies, have dropped at least 2% apiece due to ongoing regulatory concerns.

The 10-year rate fell three basis points as Treasuries gained. Despite the euro's losses, the dollar was somewhat higher. Officials from the European Central Bank are set to take a break from sketching a road out of exceptional stimulus measures at today's meeting as they examine an unusual inflation shock and an unclear impact to economic growth as a result of the Ukraine conflict.

After a 13 percent drop on Wednesday, Russia's currency traded modestly higher at 119.20 per dollar. The yuan trading bank for the ruble was doubled by China amid signs of troubled liquidity as banks shied away from making transactions.

After a dramatic spike in digital tokens inspired by excitement over an imminent US overhaul of crypto supervision that could provide regulatory clarity for investors, Bitcoin fell back below $40,000 in cryptocurrency trading.
